children.name: when two facts, events, or situations are connected
connection
children.definition: the way in which two facts, ideas, events etc are related to each other, and one is affected or caused by the otherSYN link
examples: connection between
thecausal connectionbetween smoking and cancer
There is a connectionbetween pollution and the death of trees.
connection with
Mr O'Harahadno knownconnectionwith terrorist activity.
connection to
Williams apparentlyhasnoconnectionto the case.
Police have so far failed toestablishaconnectionbetween the two murders.
The evidence was there in the file but no onemade the connection.
Students oftenseelittleconnectionbetween school and the rest of their lives.
He demonstratedthe close connectionbetween social conditions and health.
a close/strong connectionthe close connection between maths and physics

children.name: have a connection
children.definition: with/to something
examples: A lot of social problems have a direct connection to alcohol or drug use.

children.name: see a connection
examples: It's easy to see a connection between stress and illness.

children.name: make a connection
examples: In learning to read, children make a connection between a written sign and a known sound or word.

children.name: establish a connection
children.definition: show that there is one
examples: Scientists have attempted to establish a connection between these two theories.

children.name: discover/find a connection
examples: This is the first official investigation to find a connection.

children.name: something suggests a connection
examples: There is nothing to suggest a connection between the hospital food and the illness.

children.name: break a connection
children.definition: stop it existing
examples: We must break the connection between money and politics.

children.name: sever a connection
children.definition: break it
examples: We cannot sever our connection with the past.

children.name: a direct connection
examples: Many people see a direct connection between these events.

children.name: an intimate connection
children.definition: a very close connection
examples: There is an intimate connection between political liberty and economic freedom.

children.name: a causal connection
children.definition: that causes or is caused by something else
examples: Psychologists have established a causal connection between behaviour and rewards.

children.name: a clear/obvious connection
examples: There is an obvious connection between this painting and his earlier works.

children.name: a loose connection
children.definition: alsoa tenuous connectionformal
examples: (= one that is not strong, close, or obvious )There seemed to be only a loose connection between the questions and the answers.

children.name: relationship
children.definition: the way in which two things are connected andaffecteach other, or the way in which the connectioncanbeexplained:
examples: Interest rates and government spending are connected, but the relationship is quite a complex one.
relationship between
the relationship between diet and health problems
relationship to/with
These accusations against me have no relationship to the truth.
He’s studying politics and its relationship to the media.
The lessonsbear little relationship(= they are not connected to )the children’s needs.

children.name: a close relationship
examples: The evidence points to a close relationship between poverty and disease.

children.name: a strong/significant relationship
examples: Studies show a significant relationship between smoking and heart disease.

children.name: a direct relationship
children.definition: when one thing has an effect or influence on another, without any other things being involved
examples: There is a direct relationship between the demand for a particular product and its price.

children.name: an inverse relationshiptechnical
children.definition: so that when one is great, the other is small
examples: We concluded that there will be an inverse relationship between the market price of the bond and its true yield.

children.name: a causal relationship
children.definition: when one thing causes another
examples: the causal relationship between cigarette smoking and lung cancer

children.name: bear no/little relationship to something
examples: The allegations bore no relationship to the facts.

children.name: establish a relationship
children.definition: prove that it exists
examples: The book tries to establish a relationship between the war and social unrest in Europe.

children.name: a relationship exists
examples: No relationship exists between the size of the prison population and the level of crime.

children.name: link
children.definition: 1a way in which two things or ideas are related to each other
examples: link between something (and something)
the link between drug use and crime
There are a number of links between the two theories.
2a relationship or connection between two or more people, countries, organizations etc
link between
theclose linkbetween teacher and student
link with
The company hasstrong linkswith big investors.
forge/establish links
Organizers of the project hope that international links will be forged.

children.name: correlation
children.definition: if there is a correlation between two things, they happen orexisttogetherand it seems likely that onecausesorinfluencesthe other: mối tương quan
examples: correlation between
a strong correlation between urban deprivation and poor health
strong/high/close/significant etc correlation
There is a direct correlation between the best-known brands and the best-selling brands.
correlation with
There’s also some correlation with social class.

children.name: a significant correlation
examples: There is no significant correlation between age and work performance.

children.name: a strong/high/close correlation
examples: They found evidence of a high correlation between drinking and violence.

children.name: a direct correlation
examples: Research shows a direct correlation between TV viewing and poor academic work.

children.name: a clear/obvious correlation
examples: There is a clear correlation between carbon dioxide emissions and global warming.

children.name: a positive correlation
children.definition: showing that two things are likely to exist together
examples: They found a positive correlation between good diet and life expectancy.

children.name: a negative correlation
children.definition: showing that two things are not likely to exist together
examples: Is there a negative correlation between a person's weight and the distance they walk on an average day?

children.name: show a correlation
examples: Studies have shown a correlation between recession and property crime.

children.name: find a correlation
examples: Researchers failed to find any correlation between the two.

children.name: observe a correlation
examples: A correlation has been observed between untidiness and creativity.

children.name: a correlation exists between something and something
examples: A strong correlation exists between social class and exam success.

children.name: to be connected with a fact, event, idea etc
related
children.definition: be connected/be  iftwothings are connected or related, there is a relationship between them:
examples: ▪ It seems likely that the western diet and high levels of heart disease are connected.
▪ It’s fairly obvious that pollution and heavy car use are related.:

children.name: be connected with sth
examples: ▪ Changes in moral values tend to be connected with changes in a society’s economic standing.
▪ The most common illnesses among VDU operators are connected with the eyes and vision.

children.name: be closely connected/related
examples: ▪ Diet and exercise are closely connected with overall health.
▪ Studies suggest that cigarette advertising is closely related to adolescents’ smoking behavior.

children.name: be related to sth
examples: ▪ Each country has its own problems, which are related to its economic and political position.
▪ Families reported widespread hardship directly related to absentee or alcoholic fathers.

children.name: related issues/problems etc
examples: ▪ Leaders will meet to discuss the debt crisis, investment and other related issues.

children.name: linked
children.definition: be  iftwothings are linked, oneaffectsorcausesthe other, although the connection is not always easy to see and cannot always be proved:
examples: ▪ Drug dealing and prostitution are often linked.

children.name: be linked with/to
examples: ▪ Aluminium in water is now being linked with premature ageing.

children.name: have sth to do with
children.definition: have/be sth to do with especiallyspokento be connected in a way that you donotunderstandclearly:
examples: I don’t know much about his job, but it has something to do with finance.

children.name: ‘What’s wrong with your car?’ ‘I’m not sure. I think it’s something to do with the starter motor.’
associated
children.definition: problems that are associated with a particular situation or event, are likely to happen because of it: liên quan ( tới cái gì là nguyên nhân của vấn đề đó )
examples: ▪ The group tours schools, talking to kids about drug abuse and its associated problems.
▪ I was warned by the doctor about the associated side effects of the new treatment.

children.name: be associated with sth
examples: ▪ Low educational achievement is strongly associated with poverty and disadvantage.

children.name: go hand in hand
children.definition: / be bound up withC2 especially UK if sth is bound up with or goes hand in hand with something else, the two things are verycloselyconnected and need to beconsideredtogether: có mối liên hệ mật thiết/gần gũi/chặt chẽ
examples: ▪ His problems are all bound up with his relationship with his parents.
▪ In most societies, wealth and power go hand in hand.
▪ According to Marx, the decline of feudalism was bound up with the growth of towns in the twelfth century.

children.name: go hand in hand with sth
examples: ▪ Scientists have noticed that climate changes seem to go hand in hand with sea-level changes.

children.name: connected with the subject being discussed
relevant
children.definition: directly connected with the subject you are discussing or considering: liên quan
examples: ▪ We can’t make a decision until we have all the relevant information.
▪ The judge ruled that the defendant’s previous conviction was relevant and could be discussed during the case.

children.name: relevant to
examples: ▪ I don’t think your arguments are relevant to this discussion.

children.name: pertinent
children.definition: sth that is pertinent to a subject isdirectlyconcerned with it and isimportantwhen considering it: thích đáng, đúng chỗ, thích hợp, thẳng vào vấn đề
examples: ▪ That’s a very pertinent question.
▪ I think it may be pertinent at this point to raise the question of how the new department will be funded.

children.name: pertinent to
examples: ▪ The police department is appealing for any information that may be pertinent to this inquiry.

children.name: not related
children.definition: not connected/
examples: ▪The two diseases seem similar, but they are not related in any way.
not connected/not related with:
▪ The group is not connected with any politica:

children.name: unrelated
children.definition: /unconnectedformalnot connected in any way: không liên quan, không có mối liên hệ/kết nối
examples: ▪ The two robberies are said to be unconnected.

children.name: unrelated to sth/unconnected with sth
examples: ▪ A spokesperson claimed that Hoyle’s dismissal was completely unrelated to his recent criticism of the club.

children.name: have no connection with
children.definition: especially written to not be connected with something in any way:
examples: ▪ His comment had absolutely no connection with what we were talking about.

children.name: have nothing to do with
children.definition: be/ to not be connected with sth or sb in any way: không có liên quan gì tới
examples: ▪ Those boxes are nothing to do with me. Sally left them there.
▪ Your age has nothing to do with your ability to do the job.

children.name: to be connected with an organization
be connected with
children.definition: có liên quan tới, có mối liên hệ với
examples: She’s not a professor but she’s connected with the university in some way.
Senators are demanding to know whether the vice-president is in any way connected with the arms suppliers.

children.name: have links with
children.definition: have links/connections with to have a relationship with an organization, group, or country: có mối quan hệ với / liên quan đến
examples: ▪ He is believed to have connections with extremist fundamentalist groups.
have close links/connections with something :
▪ South Korea continues to have close military links with the US.
sever/cut/break off links with something:end your relationship with them :
▪ Lipman called for the U.S. to sever links with countries known to support terrorists.

children.name: be linked with
children.definition: to be connected with an organization, activity or event - use this especially when youdo not approve ofthe connection: có liên quan tới, liên hệ với, dính líu với
examples: Police are still saying the Mafia may be linked with the shooting.

children.name: not connected with the subject being dicussed
irrelevant
children.definition: không liên quan
examples: ▪ Chris continued to annoy her with questions on totally irrelevant subjects.
Chris cứ liên tục làm phiền cô ta với những câu hỏi về những chủ đề không liên quan
▪ ‘But I didn’t know it was illegal to park here.’ ‘That’s completely irrelevant.’
"Nhưng tôi không có biết là đỗ xe ở đây là vi phạm luật" "Điều đó không có liên quan"
irrelevant to: không liên quan tới
▪ To many young people, the church seems outdated and irrelevant to modern times.
Đối với nhiều thanh niên trẻ, nhà thơ dường như đã quá lỗi thời và không có mối quan hệ nào với thời hiện đại
irrelevantly[adverb]một cách không liên quan
▪ ‘In this light,’ I said, irrelevantly, ‘my hand looks blue.’
"Dưới nguồn ánh sáng này" Tôi nói một cách không liên quan "Tay của tôi có màu xanh"

children.name: that’s beside the point
children.definition: say this when you think that what someone has said does not have any real connection with what you arearguingabout: đó là chuyện ngoài lề, điều đó chẳng liên quan
examples: ▪ ‘Is she married or single?’ ‘That’s completely beside the point - the question is, does she have the ability to do the job?’

children.name: what has that got to do with
children.definition: ...? Britishspoken/what does that have to do with ...?especially American,spoken say this when someone has mentioned something and youcannotunderstandhow it is connected with the subject you are talking about:
examples: Có liên quan gì đến ... ?
▪ I realize you didn’t get home until after midnight but what does that have to do with coming in late for work
Tôi biết là anh phải làm tới sau nửa đêm mới về nhà nhưng nó thì có gì liên quan tới việc anh đi làm trễ

children.name: have nothing to do with
children.definition: be/ if sth has nothing to do with a subject, it is not connected with it in any way: không liên quan gì tới ( một chủ đề )
examples: My back was bothering me a little bit, but that had nothing to do with how badly I played.
I don’t know what’s the matter with Billy -- he says it’s nothing to do with school.
My father was a remote figure who had nothing to do with my everyday life.

children.name: doesn’t come into it
children.definition: / doesn’t enter into itspokensay this about sth that sb has mentioned that does notinfluenceoraffectwhat you are talking about: chẳng liên quan
examples: Whether the applicant is a man or a woman doesn’t come into it.
I’m afraid this is company policy, and your own views on the matter simply don’t enter into it.

children.name: neither here nor there
children.definition: be spokensay this when sb has mentioned sth that they think isimportantbut you donotagree: đâu có quan trọng
examples: ▪ What I think about your husband is neither here nor there.
▪ It’s true we’re not friends but that’s neither here nor there. We’re still able to work together.

children.name: have no bearing on sth
children.definition: if something has no bearing on the situation that you are talking about, it does not affect that situation or help to explain it: chẳng liên quan gì
examples: ▪ The president’s age has no bearing on whether or not I will vote for him.
▪ A suspect’s previous criminal record should have no bearing on the trial.

children.name: red herring
children.definition: facts or information that are not connected with the subject that is being discussed or considered, and take people’s attention away from what is really important: sự đánh trống lảng
examples: Concerns about the cost of the project are a red herring.

children.name: to make a connection between two or more things or people
link
children.definition: 1 make connection to make a connection between two or more things or people:
examples: A love of nature links the two poets.
link something and something
Police are linking the availability of alcohol and a recent rise in the number of teenage arrests.
link something/somebody to/with something
Exactly how do we link words to objects?
His name has been linked with several famous actresses since he and his wife separated last year.
The health department has linked several cases of food poisoning with contaminated shellfish.
link somebody/something together
Strong family ties still linked them together.
2 show connection[T] to show or say that there is a connection between two people, situations, or things
link something/somebody to/with something
He denied reports linking him to Colombian drug dealers.
For centuries farmers have linked the behavior of animals and plants to changes in the weather.

children.name: associate
children.definition: to make a connection in your mind between one thing or person and another: liên tưởng

children.name: associate sb/sth with sth
examples: I don’t associate him with energetic sports.
Shoppers tend to associate certain brand names with high quality.
People associate the old days with good times, and seem to forget the hardship they endured.

children.name: associate sb/sth and sth
examples: I’ve always associated the smell of paint and my first grade art class.

children.name: make a connection
children.definition: torealizethat two things are connected:
examples: At least 24 women who took the diet pills developed heart disease before doctors made the connection.

children.name: make a connection between
examples: Young children quickly make a connection between the pictures in books and the real objects they see.

children.name: establish a link
children.definition: toproveordiscoverthat sth is connected with sth else:

children.name: establish a link between
examples: Police have so far failed to establish a link between the two murders.
Sir Austin Bradford Hill led one of the first research teams to establish a link between smoking and lung cancer.

children.name: apply
children.definition: verbRELATE TO

children.name: concern
children.definition: verbINVOLVE

children.name: context
children.definition: nounCAUSE OF EVENT

children.name: the situation within which something exists or happens, and that can help explain it
examples: _It is important to see all the fighting and bloodshed in his playsinhistorical context.
_This small battle is very importantin thecontextofScottish history.

children.name: relation
children.definition: a connection between two or more thingsSYN relationship
examples: relation between
the relation between prices and wages
The price the meat is sold forbears no relation to(= is not connected to )the price the farmer receives.
Shebearsno relationto(= She is not similar to) her brother.
The relationbetweenthe original bookandthis new film is very faint.

children.name: with
children.definition: prepositionRELATIONSHIP

children.name: relating to or in the case of a person or thing
examples: _How are things with you?
_Russia has just drawn up a trade agreement withNorway.
_This hasn't got anything to do with you (= This is not something you should be interested in) .
_The government's policies have not been popular with (= among) the voters.
_He's very careless with his money.
_She talked a lot about her relationship withCharlotte.

children.name: to do with
children.definition: connected with
examples: _"Why did you want to talk to me?" "Well, it's to do with a complaint that's been made about your work."
_"But I didn't have any money." "Whathasthat got to do with it? You still shouldn't have taken my purse without asking me."
_She's refused tohave anything (more)to do with him since he was arrested for drinking and driving.
_"I thought I should tell you I saw your son smoking today." "Mind your own business, would you? Ithas nothingto do with you what my son does!"

children.name: in/with relation to sth
children.definition: in/with relation tosth

children.name: in connection with something
examples: _She used the map to discover where she was in relation to her surroundings.

children.name: bond
children.definition: verbMAKE CONNECTION

children.name: to develop a close connection or strong relationship with someone
examples: _The aim was to bond the group into a closely-knit team.
_The hospital gives mothers no quiet private time in which to bondwiththeir babies.

children.name: refer to
children.definition: sb/sthphrasal verb

children.name: If writing or information refers to someone or something, it relates to that person or thing
examples: _The new salary scale only refers to company managers and directors.
3if a statement, number, report etc refers to someone or something, it is about that person or thing :
The figures refer to our sales in Europe.

children.name: respective
children.definition: adjective

children.name: relating or belonging to each of the separate people or things you have just mentioned
examples: _Everyone would go into the hall for assembly and then afterwards we'd go to our respective classes.
_Clinton and Zedillo ordered their respective Cabinets to devise a common counter-drug strategy.

children.name: equate
children.definition: verb

children.name: to consider one thing to be the same as or equal to another thing
examples: _He complained that there was a tendency to equate right-wing politicswithself-interest.

children.name: relate
children.definition: verbCONNECT

children.name: to find or show the connection between two or more things
examples: _Researchers are trying to relate low exam resultsand/to/withlarge class sizes.

children.name: relative to
children.definition: If something is  something else, it varies

children.name: according to the speed or level of the other thing
examples: _The amount of petrol a car uses is relative to its speed.

children.name: attach
children.definition: sthtosthphrasal verbslightly formal

children.name: To attach a particular quality to something is to consider it to have that quality
examples: _I don't attach any importance/significance to these rumours.
_She attaches great value to being financially independent.

children.name: over
children.definition: prepositionCONNECTED WITH

children.name: (referring to a cause of interest, worry, discussion, etc.) connected with or about
examples: _There's no point in arguing over something so unimportant.
_I need time totalk/thinkover your proposal (= to discuss/consider it carefully) .
_The legal battle was over who should have custody of the child.
